content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two separate pieces of tissue, which appear to be two lymph nodes surrounded by adipose tissue. Both nodes are largely replaced by dark purple (basophilic) cell populations, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. The normal lymph node architecture seems to be almost completely effaced. The node on the right has a central pale area, which could represent necrosis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the lower-left lymph node. This node contains a large, confluent, basophilic deposit that is very suspicious for metastasis. The selected area is at the peripheral interface between the suspicious tumor deposit and the surrounding adipose tissue. The main goal is to confirm the malignant nature of these cells and, critically, to assess for the presence of extranodal extension (tumor invading beyond the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat), which is an important prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lower-left lymph node. This area represents the densest part of the cellular infiltrate that is replacing the normal lymph node tissue. The purpose of this high-power examination is to closely inspect the cytology of these infiltrating cells to confirm if they are malignant epithelial cells, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma, as opposed to a lymphoproliferative process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the densely cellular, dark purple area of the lower-left lymph node. My goal is to confirm the suspicion of metastasis. At high power, I need to examine the cytology of these cells to determine if they are malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma) or reactive lymphocytes. The area selected is a representative part of the suspicious deposit, allowing for a definitive diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node on the left. While there is a large, obvious tumor mass in the lower part of this node, the selected area is a smaller, more diffusely infiltrated focus at the periphery. I would examine this area to: 1) Confirm that this separate focus is also metastatic tumor. 2) Assess the pattern of infiltration at the edge of the node. 3) Look for evidence of extranodal extension, which is the invasion of tumor cells into the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. Examining less dense areas of infiltration is crucial for a complete assessment. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the lower-left lymph node, which appears to be almost completely effaced by tumor. I have zoomed into the periphery of the nodal tissue, at the interface between the dense tumor infiltrate and the surrounding perinodal fat. The primary reason for investigating this specific area is to assess for extranodal extension (ENE). ENE is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding adipose tissue, which is a critical prognostic factor. This interface is the best location to identify such invasion. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the second lymph node from the left (the one on the right). The zoom area is located at the periphery of the large tumor deposit. I would zoom into this specific area to assess the interface between the metastatic tumor and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The key question is whether the tumor is confined within the lymph node capsule or has breached it to invade the surrounding fat. This feature, known as extranodal extension (ENE), is a very important prognostic factor and must be reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the lower-left lymph node. The large basophilic area is highly suspicious for metastasis. I am zooming into the area in the green box because it shows the interface between the tumor deposit and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. This is a critical area to examine in order to assess for the presence of extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat. ENE is a significant prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a clear demarcation between two types of tissue. On the right, there is a dense sheet of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and minimal cytoplasm, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. On the left, there is mature adipose tissue. The tumor cells are seen directly infiltrating the adipose tissue without a clear intervening lymph node capsule. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with definite metastatic carcinoma and clear evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At this magnification, I see a dense infiltrate composed predominantly of small, dark lymphocytes. However, scattered throughout this lymphoid stroma, there are clusters and single, larger atypical cells. These cells have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic nuclei. While well-formed glands are not evident in this specific field, the presence of these malignant-appearing epithelial cells within the lymph node parenchyma confirms the diagnosis of metastatic carcinoma. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is completely replaced by dense sheets of small, round, dark blue (hyperchromatic) cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and scant cytoplasm. These cells are monotonous in appearance. There are also prominent empty white spaces, which are adipocytes (fat cells), indicating that the tumor is infiltrating into the perinodal fat. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, completely effaced by metastatic carcinoma. The presence of tumor in the surrounding fat would be classified as extranodal extension.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see nests and clusters of malignant glandular cells infiltrating the fibro-adipose tissue. The cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with adenocarcinoma. These tumor cells are surrounded by a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes. The key finding is the presence of these malignant glands within the adipose tissue (the large, empty white spaces) outside the main lymphoid parenchyma. This confirms metastatic adenocarcinoma to this lymph node and, importantly, demonstrates extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a clear interface between dense lymphoid tissue (left) and perinodal adipose tissue (right and bottom). Infiltrating between the adipocytes and extending from the main nodal mass, there are irregular nests and tongues of atypical epithelial cells. These cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. A prominent, thick-walled vessel, possibly a vein or lymphatic, is also visible. The presence of tumor cells within the perinodal fat confirms my suspicion of extranodal extension (ENE). This is a positive lymph node with ENE.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a dense sheet of malignant cells with dark, irregularly shaped (pleomorphic) nuclei and scant cytoplasm. These malignant cells are clearly seen infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue, dissecting between individual fat cells (adipocytes). This finding confirms that the tumor is not confined to the lymph node. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the left side shows a dense, solid proliferation of malignant cells with large, dark, irregular nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. On the right is mature adipose tissue. The crucial finding is that the tumor cells are directly infiltrating into the fat, with no intervening lymph node capsule visible. The tumor is intermingled with the adipocytes. My impression is that this confirms metastatic adenocarcinoma in the lymph node with clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
